pull.title: lint: Converting lint-assertions.sh to lint-assertions.py
pull.body: This PR is converting `test/lint/lint-assertions.sh` to `test/lint/lint-assertions.py`. It's an item of #24783.

events.body: I guess you should squash your commits, see: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#squashing-commits

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,57 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env python3
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2018-2022 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+#
+# Check for assertions with obvious side effects.
+
+import sys
+
+from subprocess import check_output, CalledProcessError
+
+
+def exec_cmd(command: [], error_msg: ""):
+    try:
+        output = check_output(command, universal_newlines=True, encoding="utf8")
+        print(error_msg)
+        print(output)
+        return 1
+    except CalledProcessError as ex1:
+        if ex1.returncode > 1:
+            raise ex1
+    return 0
+
+
+def main():
+    # PRE31-C (SEI CERT C Coding Standard):
+    # "Assertions should not contain assignments, increment, or decrement operators."
+    exit_code = exec_cmd([
+        "git",
+        "grep",
+        "-E",
+        r"[^_]assert\(.*(\+\+|\-\-|[^=!<>]=[^=!<>]).*\);",
+        "--",
+        "*.cpp",
+        "*.h"
+    ], "Assertions should not have side effects:")
+
+    # Macro CHECK_NONFATAL(condition) should be used instead of assert for RPC code, where it
+    # is undesirable to crash the whole program. See: src/util/check.h
+    # src/rpc/server.cpp is excluded from this check since it's mostly meta-code.
+    exit_code += exec_cmd([

@@ -0,0 +1,57 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env python3
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2018-2022 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+#
+# Check for assertions with obvious side effects.
+
+import sys
+
+from subprocess import check_output, CalledProcessError
comments.body: nit: the code will more clearer if we import subprocess and then make calls using `subprocess.check_output` and so on.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,56 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env python3
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2018-2022 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+#
+# Check for assertions with obvious side effects.
+
+import sys
+import subprocess
+
+
+def exec_cmd(command: [], error_msg: ""):
+    try:
+        output = subprocess.check_output(command, universal_newlines=True, encoding="utf8")
+        print(error_msg)
+        print(output)
+        return 1
+    except subprocess.CalledProcessError as ex1:
+        if ex1.returncode > 1:
comments.body: Why check for a return code larger than 1 here? The original script doesn't check return codes at all. As we've discussed in other linter reviews, it's fine to leave out this `except` and let a `CalledProcessError` escalate. This only hapens if git fails.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,56 @@

+#

+

+import subprocess
+
+

comments.body: Would prefer not to have this wrapper and use `subprocess.check_output` directly below where relevant. The amount of shared code is minimal, no need to define a function.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,56 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env python3
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2018-2022 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+#
+# Check for assertions with obvious side effects.
+
+import sys
+import subprocess
+
+
+def exec_cmd(command: [], error_msg: ""):
+    try:
+        output = subprocess.check_output(command, universal_newlines=True, encoding="utf8")
+        print(error_msg)
+        print(output)
+        return 1
+    except subprocess.CalledProcessError as ex1:
+        if ex1.returncode > 1:
comments.body:
When the output of grep is empty the return code will be 1, it in the bash script it don't stop the execution because it in a `$()`, that will get only output ignoring the exit code.
The idea here is expect the `CalledProcessError.returncode` equal 1 to have sure if command output is empty.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,56 @@
+#!/usr/bin/env python3
+#
+# Copyright (c) 2018-2022 The Bitcoin Core developers
+# Distributed under the MIT software license, see the accompanying
+# file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
+#
+# Check for assertions with obvious side effects.
+
+import sys
+import subprocess
+
+
+def exec_cmd(command: [], error_msg: ""):
+    try:
+        output = subprocess.check_output(command, universal_newlines=True, encoding="utf8")
+        print(error_msg)
+        print(output)
+        return 1
+    except subprocess.CalledProcessError as ex1:
+        if ex1.returncode > 1:
comments.body:
OK, that makes sense. Do you know if this behavior of `git grep` is documented anywhere? The manual page doesn't mention anything about return codes.

Edit: apparently this is expected behavior because `grep` does it:
```
EXIT STATUS
       Normally the exit status is 0 if a line is selected, 1 if no lines were selected, and 2 if an error  occurred.
       However,  if  the  -q  or  --quiet or --silent is used and a line is selected, the exit status is 0 even if an
       error occurred.
```

comments.body: Fair enough. Though this logic is specific to `git grep`. It makes sense to make it a  `git_grep` wrapper specifically.
